Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Strategies: The Robot Algebra Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Robot Algebra Project creates three scalable, middle school level units for use in informal settings. The units are designed around fundamental robot movement concepts but emphasize proportional reasoning - a big idea in mathematics. There are over 12,000 FIRST Lego League teams across the U.S. that purport to use robots as a motivator to engage students in STEM. However, most of the time the students use guess and check procedures thwarting the opportunity to learn STEM content. The units being developed build upon model eliciting activities, project-based learning and mathematics education to specifically improve student understanding of a few key mathematics concepts. The programming of robots is scaffolded so that students concentrate on the mathematics. Rather than only doing hands-on activities, the students also produce toolkits for other students to engage in similar experiments. Paper- based word problems are developed to bridge the mathematics learned in the context of robotics to generalized mathematical problem-solving strategies. Professional development is provided both face-to-face and through webinars to early adopters who are also trained to provide professional development to others. Materials to supplement the professional development are produced to support teachers and informal educators understanding of the rationale, the agenda, the mathematics and the perspectives that underlie the student materials as well as to also support them in anticipating student responses to the tasks. The materials can be updated online.

Pre and post tests against a control group in standard robotics programs are used to provide formative and summative evaluation. Ten students are interviewed each year about how the experiences affect their career choice. The scalability of the use of the units is measured through observation of and interviews with teachers. In the third year the units will be used in beta sites.

The fundamental goal of the current proposal is to improve middle school level student's algebraic reasoning ability, specifically their understanding of proportionality. A secondary but critically related goal is to improve informal educator's pedagogical content knowledge with respect to algebraic reasoning ability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robotics research and development, like other engineering fields, involves a large amount of mathematics. Robotics education, by contrast, involves a mixed bag of mathematics-involved and mathematics-free learning experiences. We have been iteratively been exploring the kinds of mathematics experiences that existing in particular mathematics curricula, strategies that emphasize developmentally-appropriate mathematics, barriers in design and deployment that prevent engagement with this mathematics, and design strategies that overcome these barriers.

 

In this project, we iteratively worked on curriculum units with physical and virtual robots, and with teacher-led and intelligent-tutoring-system instruction. Through our observations and analysis, we came to see this project as having four important layers:

1)    The teaching layer: what do adults contribute? Intelligent tutors were developed because informal educators (and technology educators in classrooms) tend to be weak both in understanding of mathematics and mathematics pedagogy. However, the adults are still part of the teaching system, for good or bad.  Some educator simply left students alone with the intelligent tutor. Some educators interacted directly with students, ignoring the tutor. Some educators interacted directly with the tutor, ignoring the students. Finally, some educators worked with students about the mathematical contents of the tutor. The latter strategy was associated with student gains in mathematics from pre to post. Further, only educators with high pedagogical content knowledge regarding proportional reasoning used that successful strategy as a primary instructional strategy, and educators with lowest pedagogical content knowledge never used that instructional strategy.

2)    The intelligent tutoring layer: what kind of design features best support learning? Intelligent tutoring systems can be configured in many ways. How should tasks and transitions between tasks be configured to improve mathematics learning, changing students from mechanical/procedural button clickers to mathematics learners? The analysis of the first version of the intelligent tutor found that almost no pages had significant cognitive demand: students could plug and chug without thinking at all about why they were doing the steps they were asked to do. A revision of the tutor produced a version in which a large plurality of pages required some attention to the mathematical content. The think alouds shown a strong predictive relationship between how a task was design and how students enacted that page, however with significant loss. That is, a low demand page never resulted in students thinking about their work, but a high demand page only sometimes resulted in students thinking about their work. Several design factors were associated with this loss. For example, some pages included performance accountability, in that students could not progress to the next unit until they showed some un-aided proficiency whereas other pages (for technical reasons) did not have such performance accountabilities. These pages were more likely to be treated superficially by students, even if the tasks contained on these pages were inherently rich.
